text:
hey everyone welcome to pai's kitchen today we 
are going to make chicken lettuce wrap now the

inspiration of this dish came from Peking Duck 
so you know how when you go to a restaurant a

Chinese restaurant you order Peking Duck it's only 
the skin and then they take the meat and turn it

into a lettuce wrap so I really like that lettuce 
wrap and I wanted to find a way to recreate those

flavors at home without having to go through the 
process of ordering a Peking duck and then I came

up with this recipe which I have to say is just 
as good if not better than the duck version so

let's get started so this dish is actually really 
easy it's just a simple sur fry but the sauce is

what's key so I've got here some oyster sauce and 
to this I'm going to add some soy sauce now this

is actually not the Thai soy sauce you see me 
use on hot I kitchen this is the Filipino soy

sauce that I use for my chicken adobo and again 
what I want is a darker richer flavor you can

of course use Chinese soy sauce and just Thai soy 
sauce is a little bit light for what I'm going for

hoisin paste now I say hoisin paste because that's 
sort of what it says on the jar and it's a little

thicker than hoisin sauce if you have hoisin sauce 
you can use hoisin sauce just use maybe a little

bit more than what I'm using and if you don't know 
what Hassan sauce is I like to describe it as a

sweet Chinese barbecue sauce basically so it's 
got a really nice rich sweet flavor and we won't

need to add any more sugar next is my Thai side 
coming through I am adding a little bit of tamarin

because I feel that the acidity really brightens 
up everything and sesame oil toasted sesame oil

adds a beautiful nutty aroma OOP not too much 
that's iconic of a lot of Chinese and Japanese

dishes and then since this is really thick thin 
it out a little bit with water so it's easier when

I pour it not too much there you go and the touch 
of white pepper so give it a subtle heat you don't

have to make this spicy but I am going to make 
it spicy because I like it like that by adding

just the touch of chili flakes and this is just 
chili flakes that I have at home roasted chili

flakes made by Thai dried chilies there you go 
that's about good I just want a little bit and you

can use whatever spicy you can even add chopped 
jalapeno in the mix so anything that's relatively

neutral in flavor and half spiciness all right 
that's the sauce and then the next thing we're

going to do is we want to cook everything in the 
wok so go to walk here and I'm going to add just

a little bit of vegetable oil I'm going to start 
by sauteing our aromatics and that is some onion

some chopped garlic and some finely finely minced 
ginger and I'm going to just cook this until the

onions are translucent just to get all those 
flavors infused into the oil soften the onion

a little bit now I'm going to add the key flavor 
of this session that is five-spice powder now

five-spice powder you can buy from the store or I 
have a recipe for it too if you want to grind your

own fresh Oh give it a few seconds to toast the 
bloom all those spices Oh smells so good and now

in goes the chicken so I'm using ground chicken 
you can do ground turkey got duck even better now

your biggest job is to try to get the lumps out 
of this ground chicken sometimes I find adding

a little water helps loosen it a bit there you go 
cuz chicken is so lean if you're using like ground

pork or something a little fattier or even ground 
chicken that's not as clean as this one it would

be easier to spread it apart okay so once you no 
longer have big clumps I want to add the sauce

when the chicken is still sort of undercooked 
to allow the chicken to really absorb the sauce

looks good okay nice beautiful color okay and 
now I'm going to add my vegetable so I've got

two types of vegetables that I'm using and they 
want crunchy crunchy that's what these veggies are

for some carrots dice and also for some color and 
some water chestnuts which is pretty classic when

it comes to lettuce wrap I just use canned water 
chestnuts I couldn't find fresh if you can find

fresh go for it if you don't like water chestnuts 
I find that for this you don't really taste them

it's all about texture but if you don't want to 
use water chestnuts you can do jicama now I'm

going to cheat a little bit to make this color 
really dark because usually when it's made with

duck duck meat is so much darker so I'm going to 
add black soy sauce which is always my weapon when

I want that dark rich brown color without adding 
a whole lot of saltiness a new dark soy mmm all

right I like the color of that now what I want 
to do is let this cook I'm going to crank the

heat so it's too high and I want to drive out 
the liquid that's pooling at the bottom so I

really want to crank the heat and dry all of that 
off that's looking good you don't need like just

a few seconds you don't need to make it super 
dry but just so you know it's not pooling okay

so now what I'm going to do is add a little bit 
of a cornstarch slurry and basically I mix some

cornstarch with some water and this will help 
bind the sauce and so any sauce that puling at

the bottom will be coating the chicken and adding 
a little bit of cornstarch slurry will help the

viscosity of the sauce mmm now that's looking good 
you see how now the sauce is thick and you don't

have any pooling perfect I'm going to turn this 
off I'm going to throw in some green onions so

now at this point I'm going to taste it always 
want to make sure you taste your food mmm mmm

nope I'm happy with that lettuce choices I 
think iceberg lettuce is the best for this

it's a classic lettuce for lettuce wrap 
because you want that crisp crunchiness

that's refreshing that's going to contrast 
with the chicken so don't go with anything

soft and Limpy you know not green leaf lettuce 
or anything like that if you want to make sort

of appetizer size you can use Belgian and dice 
and put the chicken in those individual leaves

that's cute as well we're going to add a little 
bit of hoisin sauce to every wrap because this

is hoisin paste it's very thick I'm just going to 
dilute it with a little water and if your hoisin

sauce is already quite loose then you don't 
have to do this I'm going to use this piece

I find the softer leaves are a little easier 
because it's easier for you to fold it over so

I'm just gonna put a little bit of the hoisin 
sauce on the leaf and this will give moisture

and a little extra flavor and our filling 
oh it's still warm some toasted white sesame

seeds I'm gonna just shake on a little bit 
so cute and I think I can do this in one bite
mmm

so good I love the contrast between the warm 
filling and the cold crisp lettuce so flavorful

you can really taste the five-spice and the sesame 
oil in the placing sauce and the crunchiness from

the water chestnuts and the carrots just add a lot 
of textural contrast it's just a really fun thing

to do and if you have guests over this is actually 
an easy thing for you as a host just put out a

bunch of stuff and then you'll guess just kind of 
take care of it on their own so I hope you give

this a try so just fun fun things to do and you 
can make a whole bunch of this and this will last

you a long time because iceberg lettuce another 
thing that's good about it is that it lasts in

your fridge for quite some time so you can have it 
for tomorrow for you know the next three days if

you want it to so the recipe will be on hot Thai 
Kitchen calm when you make it don't forget to send

me a photo on Facebook Twitter or Instagram and 
subscribe to the show if you haven't done so so

you never miss an episode and I will see you 
next time for your next delicious adventure
